description: Old French entreferir, from entre- + ferir (“to hit, to strike”), itself from the Latin verb ferio.

verbs.description: interfere (third-person singular simple present interferes, present participle interfering, simple past and past participle interfered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To get involved or involve oneself, causing disturbance.
examples: I always try not to interfere with other people’s personal affairs.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, physics) (of waves) To be correlated with each other when overlapped or superposed.
examples: Correlated waves interfere to produce interesting patterns, while uncorrelated waves overlap without interfering.
Where the radio-wave signals of the two radio stations interfere the listener hears nothing but noise.

entries.meaning: (mostly of horses) To strike one foot against the opposite foot or ankle in using the legs.
(intransitive, followed by "with") To sexually molest, especially of a child.
examples: The investigation found the girls had been interfered with.
